headline: Middle curve culture
pros:
It’s a place where you can thrive for years and build a very good career if you are good at completing tasks consistently and frequently. There are a lot of opportunities to learn and grow if you’re junior and willing to work relentlessly.

If you are someone who thrives in team settings, have always been well liked by your peers and leadership regardless of the work environment - then you will find it easy here too.

Individual credit for good investment performance is democratized, but if you are senior and well liked, it will likely help you get promoted. If you’re average, you will still have a decent career.
cons:
Being scared of a negative public opinion is in the corporate DNA. This means every imaginable decision is justified and documented. If you’re a junior resource this grunt work is your job. If you’re not helping you will be quickly written off and a slow and painful decline will make you leave.

If you are someone who relies on their investments and ideas speak for themselves and don’t spend time being liked - you will eventually make a mistake and every little misstep you’ve had will be documented and used to derail you. 

 
Don’t join if you are someone who likes autonomy in decision making. your peers will be making investments while you spend your time creating educational materials for senior management about those investments.

headline: Lots of posturing, little action
pros:
People in general are quite nice, especially if you are coming from a bank - the immediate experience here is usually that everyone is open and friendly.

Benefits are in line with the rest of the street. Location is great.
cons:
If you work in back office, you are intensely de-skilled in your time here. If you work in middle office, get ready to spend almost a decade at the same level because career stagnation is super real. If you work in IT, your managers will keep revolving and they'll keep bringing in people who want flashy projects instead of trying to improve processes by listening to their employees. If you work in front office, be prepared to potentially grind just as hard as you would at a bank, but at a lower pay.

This, plus absolutely nonsensical re-orgs every year, and lots of social posturing - employees asked for detailed reports regarding pay scales, gender equality, inclusivity, pay scales relative to each other/the street, and the difference between hiring externally vs internally.... two years ago. Somehow the company is "too busy" or "unable" to procure these. It's also another one of those companies, post covid, who are pretending that employees want to come back to the office full time. Lots of mental gymnastics to make survey results into perceived excitement.

Employees are given unique links, and the results that managers receives are different than the general group. The group receives the results in aggregate, but the group heads receive version which can be grouped "where there are 5+ responses." This makes is extraordinarily easy to figure out who wrote what, as you can break down the results by several categories such as rank, gender, location. For example, in a group where there are 5 analysts and 1 associate, you can get a result for all six, but you can also get a result for the 5 analysts. It takes basic math to figure out what the associate wrote. 

The HR is NOT on your side.

headline: CPPIB
pros: For a buy-side, this company offers low to moderate stress-level work even for front-office investment roles, and therefore great work-life balance. Compensation is fair and downside is limited. Pace is a lot slower thank banks and hedge funds, which may suit some people. It is more actively managed than other pension fund, so if one is interested in smart beta strategies, this is the right place. Flat management structure.
cons: Since down-side is limited, the upside is also limited. Expected market-median compensation package and slow to moderate growth. Toronto as a city can be a con for some people who like bigger cities such as New York and London. Certain investment styles are off-limit as well so exposure to different investment styles can be limited.
